Jensen's formula, subharmonic functions

Let f(z)f\p{z}f(z) be a continuous function on the closed unit disk {z∈C∣∣z∣≤1}\set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} \leq 1}{z∈C∣∣z∣≤1} such that f(z)f\p{z}f(z) is analytic on the open disk {∣z∣<1}\set{\abs{z} < 1}{∣z∣<1} and f(0)≠0f\p{0} \neq 0f(0)=0.

  1. Prove that if 0<r<10 < r < 10<r<1 and if inf⁡∣z∣=r ∣f(z)∣>0\inf_{\abs{z}=r}\,\abs{f\p{z}} > 0inf∣z∣=r​∣f(z)∣>0, then

    12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(reiθ)∣ dθ≥log⁡∣f(0)∣.\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \geq \log\abs{f\p{0}}.2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(reiθ)∣∣​dθ≥log∣f(0)∣.

  2. Use (1) to prove that ∣{θ∈[0,2π]∣f(eiθ)}∣=0\abs{\set{\theta \in \br{0, 2\pi} \mid f\p{e^{i\theta}}}} = 0∣∣​{θ∈[0,2π]∣f(eiθ)}∣∣​=0 where again ∣E∣\abs{E}∣E∣ is the Lebesgue measure of EEE.
Solution.

  1. We will prove Jensen's formula: let rrr be so that inf⁡∣z∣=r inf⁡∣f(z)∣>0\inf_{\abs{z}=r}\, \inf \abs{f\p{z}} > 0inf∣z∣=r​inf∣f(z)∣>0. If ErE_rEr​ is the set of roots of fff in the open disk B(0,r)B\p{0, r}B(0,r) counting multiplicity, then

    12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(reiθ)∣ dθ=log⁡∣f(0)∣−∑a∈Erlog⁡∣a∣r.\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta = \log\abs{f\p{0}} - \sum_{a \in E_r} \log\frac{\abs{a}}{r}.2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(reiθ)∣∣​dθ=log∣f(0)∣−a∈Er​∑​logr∣a∣​.

    For a∈Da \in \Da∈D, consider the Blaschke product φa ⁣:D→D\func{\phi_a}{\D}{\D}φa​:D→D,

    φa(z)=z−a1−a‾z,\phi_a\p{z} = \frac{z - a}{1 - \conj{a}z},φa​(z)=1−azz−a​,

    which is a holomorphic function on the disk with the property that ∣φa(z)∣=1\abs{\phi_a\p{z}} = 1∣φa​(z)∣=1 if ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1 or ∣a∣=1\abs{a} = 1∣a∣=1. Thus, if we set

    g(z)=f(z)∏a∈Erφa/r(z/r),g\p{z} = \frac{f\p{z}}{\prod_{a \in E_r} \phi_{a/r}\p{z/r}},g(z)=∏a∈Er​​φa/r​(z/r)f(z)​,

    then ggg is a holomorphic function on D\DD which is continuous on the D‾\cl{\D}D that vanishes nowhere on ∣z∣≤r\abs{z} \leq r∣z∣≤r. Indeed, at each root a∈Era \in E_ra∈Er​ of fff, the denominator of ggg has a zero at aaa with order equal to that of its numerator. Moreover, if ∣z∣=r\abs{z} = r∣z∣=r, then ∣g(z)∣=∣f(z)∣\abs{g\p{z}} = \abs{f\p{z}}∣g(z)∣=∣f(z)∣, since all the factors in the denominator become 111.

    Hence, log⁡∣g(z)∣\log\abs{g\p{z}}log∣g(z)∣ is a harmonic function which does not vanish on ∣z∣=r\abs{z} = r∣z∣=r. By the mean value property, we have

    12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(reiθ)∣ dθ=log⁡∣g(0)∣=log⁡∣f(0)∣−∑a∈Erlog⁡∣a∣r.\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{g\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta = \log\abs{g\p{0}} = \log\abs{f\p{0}} - \sum_{a \in E_r} \log\frac{\abs{a}}{r}.2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(reiθ)∣∣​dθ=log∣g(0)∣=log∣f(0)∣−a∈Er​∑​logr∣a∣​.

    On the other hand, since ∣reiθ∣=r\abs{re^{i\theta}} = r∣∣​reiθ∣∣​=r,

    12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(reiθ)∣ dθ=12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(reiθ)∣ dθ,\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{g\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta,2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(reiθ)∣∣​dθ=2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(reiθ)∣∣​dθ,

    which proves Jensen's formula. Observe that log⁡∣a∣r<0\log\frac{\abs{a}}{r} < 0logr∣a∣​<0 for a∈Era \in E_ra∈Er​, so this gives the inequality

    12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(reiθ)∣ dθ≥log⁡∣f(0)∣,\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \geq \log\abs{f\p{0}},2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(reiθ)∣∣​dθ≥log∣f(0)∣,

    which was what we wanted to show.

  2. Since B(0,r)‾\cl{B\p{0, r}}B(0,r)​ is compact and fff does not vanish everywhere (since f(0)≠0f\p{0} \neq 0f(0)=0), it follows that fff can only have finitely many zeroes in B(0,r)‾\cl{B\p{0, r}}B(0,r)​. By writing

    D=⋃n=1∞B(0,1−1n),\D = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B\p{0, 1 - \frac{1}{n}},D=n=1⋃∞​B(0,1−n1​),

    we see that the zeroes of fff are a countable union of finite sets, so fff has at most countably many zeroes. In particular, we may pick a sequence {rn}n⊆(0,1)\set{r_n}_n \subseteq \p{0, 1}{rn​}n​⊆(0,1) such that rnr_nrn​ increases to 111 and inf⁡∣z∣=rn ∣f(z)∣>0\inf_{\abs{z}=r_n}\,\abs{f\p{z}} > 0inf∣z∣=rn​​∣f(z)∣>0, since countably many zeroes almost removes countably many choices of radii. By Fatou's lemma,

    log⁡∣f(0)∣≤lim sup⁡n→∞12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(rneiθ)∣ dθ≤12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(eiθ)∣ dθ.\begin{aligned} \log\abs{f\p{0}} \leq \limsup_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{r_ne^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{e^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta. \end{aligned}log∣f(0)∣≤n→∞limsup​2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(rn​eiθ)∣∣​dθ≤2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(eiθ)∣∣​dθ.​

    Let E={θ∈[0,2π]∣f(eiθ)=0}E = \set{\theta \in \br{0, 2\pi} \mid f\p{e^{i\theta}} = 0}E={θ∈[0,2π]∣f(eiθ)=0}. Since f(0)≠0f\p{0} \neq 0f(0)=0, we have log⁡∣f(0)∣>−∞\log\abs{f\p{0}} > -\inftylog∣f(0)∣>−∞, so if ∣E∣>0\abs{E} > 0∣E∣>0,

    −∞<log⁡∣f(0)∣≤12π∫02πlog⁡∣f(eiθ)∣ dθ=12π∫Elog⁡∣f(eiθ)∣ dθ+12π∫Eclog⁡∣f(eiθ)∣ dθ=∣E∣2π⋅(−∞)+12π∫Eclog⁡∣f(eiθ)∣ dθ.\begin{aligned} -\infty &< \log\abs{f\p{0}} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\abs{f\p{e^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_E \log\abs{f\p{e^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta + \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{E^\comp} \log\abs{f\p{e^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \\ &= \frac{\abs{E}}{2\pi} \cdot \p{-\infty} + \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_{E^\comp} \log\abs{f\p{e^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta. \end{aligned}−∞​<log∣f(0)∣≤2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(eiθ)∣∣​dθ=2π1​∫E​log∣∣​f(eiθ)∣∣​dθ+2π1​∫Ec​log∣∣​f(eiθ)∣∣​dθ=2π∣E∣​⋅(−∞)+2π1​∫Ec​log∣∣​f(eiθ)∣∣​dθ.​

    The second term is bounded, since fff is continuous on ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1, so the second term is bounded above by some finite number. Thus, if ∣E∣≠0\abs{E} \neq 0∣E∣=0, then

    −∞<log⁡∣f(0)∣≤−∞,-\infty < \log\abs{f\p{0}} \leq -\infty,−∞<log∣f(0)∣≤−∞,

    which is impossible. Hence, ∣E∣=0\abs{E} = 0∣E∣=0, as required.
